title: Create /conductor:bd-plan skill (backlog preparation)
description:
# bd-plan - Backlog Preparation

Prepare issues before working on them.

## Flow

```
/conductor:bd-plan
  │
  ├── AskUserQuestion: "What planning activity?"
  │   ├── Refine backlog (analyze, prioritize, organize waves)
  │   ├── Enhance prompts (Haiku explorers via pmux)
  │   ├── Match skills (persist to issue notes)
  │   └── Review ready (show issues ready to work)
  │
  ├── If "Refine backlog":
  │   ├── bd stats, bd ready, bd blocked
  │   ├── Identify parallelizable groups
  │   ├── Suggest priority adjustments
  │   └── Output wave plan
  │
  ├── If "Enhance prompts":
  │   ├── AskUserQuestion: which issues?
  │   ├── Spawn Haiku explorers via pmux (cheap)
  │   ├── Explorers find: files, skills, approach
  │   └── Store prepared.* fields in issue notes
  │
  ├── If "Match skills":
  │   ├── AskUserQuestion: which issues?
  │   ├── Run match-skills.sh --verify
  │   └── Persist skills to issue notes
  │
  └── If "Review ready":
      └── bd ready with details
```

## Key Points

- **Preparation phase** - Before bd-work or bd-conduct
- **Cheap exploration** - Haiku (20x cheaper than Opus)
- **Persist results** - Skills/prompts stored in beads notes
- **Optional** - Can skip straight to bd-work if issue is simple

title: Create /conductor:bd-conduct skill (multi-session orchestration)
description:
# bd-conduct - Multi-Session Orchestration

Spawn workers to tackle multiple issues in parallel.

## Flow

```
/conductor:bd-conduct
  │
  ├── AskUserQuestion: "Here are the unblocked issues:" [multiSelect]
  │
  ├── AskUserQuestion: "How many terminals?" 
  │   ├── 2 terminals
  │   ├── 3 terminals (Recommended)
  │   └── 4 terminals
  │
  ├── AskUserQuestion: "Mode?"
  │   ├── Interactive - You monitor, can intervene
  │   └── Autonomous - Runs waves until backlog empty
  │
  ├── Setup:
  │   ├── Create worktrees (bd worktree add)
  │   ├── Spawn workers via /tabz:spawn-terminal
  │   ├── Send prompts with skill hints
  │   └── Record worker sessions in beads notes
  │
  ├── Monitor:
  │   ├── Interactive: Poll status, answer questions
  │   └── Autonomous: Loop waves, /wipe at 75% context
  │
  └── Complete (wave-done):
      ├── Verify all workers done
      ├── Merge branches
      ├── Unified code review
      ├── Cleanup worktrees
      └── Push to main
```

## Key Points

- **You are the conductor** - Spawn and monitor workers
- **Workers follow PRIME.md** - They do bd-work essentially
- **Uses tabz skills** - /tabz:spawn-terminal, /tabz:send-keys
- **Wave completion** - Merge, review, cleanup at conductor level

## Dependencies

- Requires tabz plugin for spawning
- Workers get PRIME.md via beads hooks

title: Add auto-detection guardrails to completion flow
description:
# Completion Guardrails

Auto-detect whether running as standalone (bd-work) or as spawned worker (bd-conduct).

## Detection Logic

```bash
is_worker_mode() {
  # Method 1: CONDUCTOR_SESSION env var (set by bd-conduct)
  [ -n "$CONDUCTOR_SESSION" ] && return 0
  
  # Method 2: Inside git worktree
  COMMON_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-common-dir 2>/dev/null)
  GIT_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-dir 2>/dev/null)
  [ "$COMMON_DIR" != "$GIT_DIR" ] && return 0
  
  return 1  # Standalone mode
}
```

## Behavior by Mode

**Standalone (bd-work):**
- Full pipeline: verify → tests → review → commit → close → push
- You control everything

**Worker (spawned by bd-conduct):**
- Limited pipeline: verify → tests → commit → close → notify
- NO push (conductor merges)
- NO code review (conductor reviews after merge)
- MUST notify conductor

## Guardrail Messages

Worker mode:
```
⚠️ WORKER MODE DETECTED
Skipping code review and push - conductor handles this.
```

Standalone mode:
```
✓ STANDALONE MODE
Running full pipeline with code review.
```

## Integration

- Used by /conductor:worker-done
- Used by bd-work completion
- Prevents workers from accidentally pushing

description:
# Plugin Marketplace Restructuring

Migrate to ~/plugins/my-plugins with ONE marketplace containing multiple plugins.

## Target Structure

```
~/plugins/my-plugins/
├── .claude-plugin/
│   └── marketplace.json              # ONE marketplace, lists all plugins
│
└── plugins/
    ├── conductor/                     # Workflow orchestration
    │   ├── .claude-plugin/plugin.json
    │   ├── agents/
    │   │   └── conductor.md           # ONE agent
    │   └── skills/
    │       ├── plan/SKILL.md          # Backlog analysis
    │       └── work/SKILL.md          # Worker orchestration (uses /tabz:*)
    │
    ├── tabz/                          # TabzChrome integration
    │   ├── .claude-plugin/plugin.json
    │   ├── agents/
    │   │   └── tabz-expert.md         # ONE agent
    │   └── skills/
    │       ├── spawn-terminal/SKILL.md
    │       ├── send-keys/SKILL.md
    │       └── screenshot/SKILL.md
    │
    ├── code-review/                   # Code review
    │   ├── .claude-plugin/plugin.json
    │   ├── agents/
    │   │   └── reviewer.md            # ONE agent
    │   └── skills/
    │       └── review/SKILL.md
    │
    ├── frontend/                      # Frontend development
    │   ├── .claude-plugin/plugin.json
    │   ├── agents/
    │   │   └── frontend-expert.md     # ONE agent (progressive disclosure)
    │   └── skills/
    │       ├── react/SKILL.md
    │       └── ui-styling/SKILL.md
    │
    ├── backend/                       # Backend development
    │   ├── .claude-plugin/plugin.json
    │   ├── agents/
    │   │   └── backend-expert.md      # ONE agent
    │   └── skills/
    │
    └── tui-tools/                     # TUI expertise
        ├── .claude-plugin/plugin.json
        ├── agents/
        │   └── tui-expert.md          # ONE agent
        └── skills/
```

## marketplace.json Example

```json
{
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "plugins": [
    { "name": "conductor", "path": "plugins/conductor", "description": "Workflow orchestration with beads" },
    { "name": "tabz", "path": "plugins/tabz", "description": "TabzChrome spawning and browser automation" },
    { "name": "code-review", "path": "plugins/code-review", "description": "Autonomous code review" },
    { "name": "frontend", "path": "plugins/frontend", "description": "Frontend development expertise" },
    { "name": "backend", "path": "plugins/backend", "description": "Backend development expertise" },
    { "name": "tui-tools", "path": "plugins/tui-tools", "description": "TUI tools (btop, lazygit, etc.)" }
  ]
}
```

## Key Principles

1. **ONE marketplace** - User adds once, can enable/disable individual plugins
2. **ONE agent per plugin** - Each plugin has exactly one expert agent
3. **Progressive disclosure** - Agents know general patterns, invoke specific skills
4. **Separation of concerns**:
   - Tabz = HOW to spawn/interact with TabzChrome
   - Conductor = WHAT workflow to run (invokes /tabz:* skills)
5. **Beads backbone** - All workflow tracking through beads

## Migration Path

1. Create ~/plugins/my-plugins with .claude-plugin/marketplace.json
2. Create tabz plugin (spawning extracted from conductor)
3. Create conductor plugin (workflow only, uses tabz)
4. Create code-review plugin (from conductor agents)
5. Create frontend/backend/tui-tools plugins
6. Update TabzBeads to reference new location
7. Test all plugins work together

title: Unified Conductor Workflow v2
description:
# Unified Conductor Workflow v2

Phase 1 consolidation: merge bd-work, bd-swarm, bd-swarm-auto into unified commands with interactive prompts and guardrails.

See: docs/conductor-workflows.md section "PROPOSED: Unified Interactive Architecture" for full details.

## Design Decisions

### 1. Two Commands (refine + work)

Replace 4 entry points with 2 interactive commands:

```
/conductor:refine   →  Prepare issues (research phase, cheap Haiku via pmux)
/conductor:work     →  Execute issues (implementation phase, Opus workers)
```

### 2. /conductor:work AskUserQuestion Flow

```
/conductor:work
  Q1: "Here are the unblocked issues:" [multiSelect]
      → Select 1 = single worker mode (no worktree)
      → Select N = parallel workers mode (with worktrees)
  
  Q2: "How should this run?" [if N > 1]
      → Interactive = monitor, questions ok
      → Autonomous = waves until backlog empty
  
  Q3: "Worker count?" [if interactive + many issues]
      → 2, 3, 4, or "All ready issues"
```

### 3. /conductor:complete with Auto-Detection

Add guardrails to prevent workers from pushing/reviewing (conductor's job):

```
/conductor:complete <issue-id>
  Step 0: AUTO-DETECT MODE
    - CONDUCTOR_SESSION env var present → WORKER
    - Inside git worktree → WORKER
    - Otherwise → STANDALONE
  
  WORKER MODE:
    verify → tests → commit → close → notify
    ⚠️ DO NOT PUSH (conductor handles merge/review)
  
  STANDALONE MODE:
    verify → tests → code-review → commit → close → push prompt
```

Detection logic:
```bash
is_worker_mode() {
  [ -n "$CONDUCTOR_SESSION" ] && return 0  # Env var set by conductor
  COMMON_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-common-dir 2>/dev/null)
  GIT_DIR=$(git rev-parse --git-dir 2>/dev/null)
  [ "$COMMON_DIR" != "$GIT_DIR" ] && return 0  # Inside worktree
  return 1
}
```

### 4. Deprecation Strategy

- `bd-work` → alias to `/conductor:work` + deprecation notice
- `bd-swarm` → alias to `/conductor:work` + deprecation notice  
- `bd-swarm-auto` → removed (use work with "Autonomous" selection)

## Blocked Issues

This epic blocks:
- TabzBeads-y4c: Implement /conductor:work skill
- TabzBeads-6jp: Implement /conductor:complete guardrails

## Acceptance Criteria

- [x] Design unified /conductor:work flow
- [x] Design auto-detection for worker vs standalone mode
- [x] Define deprecation strategy for old commands
- [ ] y4c implements /conductor:work
- [ ] 6jp implements /conductor:complete with guardrails
close_reason: Design complete. See issue description for unified workflow v2 design. Unblocks y4c and 6jp for implementation.

title: Create /conductor:bd-work skill (standard single-session workflow)
description:
# bd-work - Standard Single-Session Workflow

YOU do the work. No spawning, no orchestration.

## Flow

```
/conductor:bd-work [issue-id]
  │
  ├── If no ID: AskUserQuestion "Here are the unblocked issues:"
  ├── Claim issue: bd update <id> --status=in_progress
  ├── Follow PRIME.md workflow
  │   ├── Implement the fix/feature
  │   ├── verify-build
  │   ├── run-tests
  │   ├── code-review (you decide)
  │   ├── commit-changes
  │   └── close-issue
  └── Push: bd sync && git push
```

## Key Points

- **No spawning** - You ARE the worker
- **Standard beads flow** - Follow PRIME.md
- **Full control** - You decide on review, tests, etc.
- **Single session** - No conductor, no workers

## When to Use

- Working on one issue at a time
- Don't need parallel workers
- Want full control over the workflow
